### From the opening of their joint workshop report, IPBES and IPCC selected authors, stated (emphasis added):

> ### Climate change ***and biodiversity loss*** are two of the most pressing issues of the Anthropocene.

<br/>

### This informational site, _And Biodiversity_, aims to serve as a resource to study the latter crisis by review of the topic, major reports, figures, quotes, data, and resources.

### Why _And Biodiversity_? To dispel common misunderstandings:

<br/>

- ### <a href="###" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#Block1">Climate change covers biodiversity loss and other environment issues</a> 

  <div id="Block1" class="collapse">  

  #### Owing to its popularity over the years, _climate change_ has become synonymous with the environment and all "green" issues and therefore encompasses all ecological crises. In reality, _climate change_ is only one issue under the umbrella of nature crises. 
  
  #### In fact, climate is just one of several planetary boundaries of the Earth System which includes biodiversity, ozone, freshwater, land use, nitrogen and phosophorus cycle, chemicals, and others. _See_ [**Figures**](figures.html) for other diagrams of planetary boundaries.

  <div class="banner">
    <img src="images/mahm_ecological_crises.jpg" alt="multiple ecological crises diagram"/>
    <p>Source: [MAHB - The End of Being](https://mahb.stanford.edu/blog/end-being-boundaries/)</p>
  </div>
  
  </div>

- ### <a href="###" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#Block2">Climate change causes biodiversity loss, so are the same thing</a> ### 

  <div id="Block2" class="collapse">  

  #### While the two crises share mutually reinforcing and overlapping causes and effects, the scientific evidence over decades demonstrates both crises are distinct issues and should not be conflated without acknowledgment of their unique and shared qualities. Consequently, the approach to solve one may negatively or positively affect the other. 

  #### _See_ [**Figures**](figures.html) that show graphics of overlap, trade-offs, and synergies between the two planetary emergencies.
  
  <div class="banner">
    <img src="images/tree_climate_biodiversity.png" alt="dry and fertile tree"/>
    <p>Source: [European Commission Article](tree_climate_biodiversity.png)</p>
  </div>
  
  </div>
  
- ### <a href="###" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#Block3">Biodiversity loss is not as immediate an issue as climate change</a> ###

  <div id="Block3" class="collapse">  

  #### For decades, scientists have asserted the devastating consequences of continued loss of biodiversity which is accelerating at unprecedented levels in human history. Such loss negatively impacts ecosystem services or nature's contribution to people such as life-critical needs of food production, soil cultivation, water availability, air quality, climate regulation, medicines, and still others.

  <div class="banner">
    <img src="images/biodiversity_emergency_banner.png" alt="biodiversity emergency protest banner"/>
    <p>Source: [Nature.com - Sustainability at the Crossroads](https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-021-03781-z)</p>
  </div>

  </div>
 
- ### <a href="###" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#Block4">Biodiversity loss is a new topic and not as well-researched or widely accepted</a> ###

  <div id="Block4" class="collapse">  

  #### Biodiversity loss has been an enduring subject matter in the ecological and environment science literature since the 1970s. It is widely accepted in science with enough impetus to erect UN's Convention for Biological Diversity in 1992 to convene global initiatives on the issue and Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) in 2012 to assess the current knowledge on the topic for policymakers. 
  
  #### _See_ [**Reports**](reports.html) that includes three global assessments across the decades (1995, 2005, and 2019) each with stark findings of rapid biodiversity loss due to human activities.

  <div class="banner" id="ipbes_reports">
    <img src="images/ipbes_covers.png" alt="IPBES report covers"/>
    <p>Source: [EcoScan - Useful Sites](https://eco-scan.fr/useful-sites-2/)</p>
  </div>

  </div>
 
- ### <a href="###" data-toggle="collapse" data-target="#Block5">Biodiversity loss is a natural phenomenon</a> ###

  <div id="Block5" class="collapse">  

  #### While species extinctions and ecosystem shifts are natural processes on Earth including five known mass extinction events, the present situation of biodiversity loss exceeds the natural occurrence in geological timescales. Also, unlike past events, the current rapid loss of biodiversity and ecosystems is mostly due to human activities. 
  
  #### _See_ [**Quotes**](quotes.html) which includes the finding from IPBES' 2019 Global Assessment: the rate of extinction is ten to hundreds of times higher than the average background rate in the last 10 million years and is accelerating. 
  
  <div class="banner">
    <img src="images/anthropocene_diagram.png" alt="Anthropocene diagram"/>
    <p>Source: [TheConversation.com Article](https://theconversation.com/an-official-welcome-to-the-anthropocene-epoch-but-who-gets-to-decide-its-here-57113)</p>
  </div>
  
  </div>
